value.name: Grinning Blackford hand in hand with new lover after his marriage broke down
value.description: Former SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford has split from his wife and started a new relationship. Mr Blackford was seen hand in hand with his new partner outside a television studio in London at the weekend.

value.name: New poll makes grim reading for SNP as huge Labour boost predicted
value.description: LABOUR’S election hopes have been boosted by another poll showing them neck and neck with Nats. The bitter rivals would be locked on 23 seats each in the Westminster vote expected later this year,

value.name: UK Covid inquiry in Scotland: Three weeks in 90 seconds
value.description: The UK Covid 19 inquiry has spent three weeks in Edinburgh looking at the decisions made in Scotland during the pandemic.

value.name: Nicola Sturgeon torn apart by Question Time audience member in brutal inquiry takedown
value.description: The former First Minister's popularity has seemingly taken a big hit during the last week's Covid inquiry evidence sessions.

value.name: Scotland set for 8.8% increase in water bills
value.description: Water bills in Scotland will increase by 8.8% from April. Scottish Water said the rise was needed to provide "significant investment" in replacing ageing infrastructure and improving services. The publicly-owned company dismissed reports that it was already planning similar-sized increases for a further two years beyond 2024.

value.name: Business can’t get enough of Labour – it’s like Corbyn never existed
value.description: Smart business leaders don’t want to micromanage every decision; they want political calm, good ministers in post, and to be left alone to run their businesses – this is what Labour offers

value.name: COLIN CAMPBELL: Covid inquiry has to do more than trash reputations
value.description: "The Covid inquiry has been highly effective in trashing the reputations or at least exposing the human flaws of the key decision-makers."

value.name: What does the restoration of power-sharing mean for Northern Ireland?
value.description: With Sinn Fein only increasing in popularity and the shuttered Belfast government looking set to reconvene, the politics of Northern Ireland is transforming before our eyes. Though talk of a united Ireland may be a bridge too far,

value.name: SNP criticise Tory/Lib Dem led Aberdeenshire Council for axeing of out-of-school care
value.description: Aberdeenshire’s primary schools will be affected with the local authority blaming a decrease in demand as well as staffing and budget pressures.

value.name: Has the UK Covid Inquiry created winners and losers?
value.description: Given the raw emotions around the UK Covid-19 Inquiry, it’s unlikely any of our politicians would talk openly about it creating winners and losers.

value.name: UK Covid Inquiry: Have winners and losers been created?
value.description: Likewise Brazil’s President Bolsonaro. Closer to home, the opposition at Holyrood have been drooling at the prospect of SNP ministers being put on the stand and eviscerated by forensic KCs. Rows over who kept their WhatsApps and who hit delete have run ...

value.name: Alex Salmond denies ministers were told in 2007 to delete messages
value.description: Nicola Sturgeon and John Swinney told the UK Covid inquiry they wiped their phones of potentially relevant evidence because of instructions received when they became ministers

value.name: ‘We’re no worse than our opponents’ is hardly a robust defence
value.description: Humza Yousaf treads a fine line between ‘we could have done better’ and ‘not to blame’

value.name: Warning over Glasgow Argyle Street revamp after Sauchiehall Street 'debacle'
value.description: A £5.8m contract has been awarded for the revamp of a section of Argyle Street, but a local councillor has warned communication with residents over planned work must be better.

value.name: ‘I don’t buy it’: Scottish secretary dismisses Sturgeon’s tears at Covid inquiry
value.description: Rishi Sunak’s Scottish secretary Alister Jack has rejected Nicola Sturgeon ’s claim she did not seek to politicise the Covid crisis – claiming he “didn’t believe her for a minute”.

value.name: Six candidates to contest Jedburgh by-election
value.description: Six candidates will contest the Jedburgh and District ward by-election, which will take place on Thursday, February 22.

value.description: Labour leader tells conference that reforms ‘may not please everyone in room’

value.name: Higher charges for Falkirk's high school swimming pools agreed to keep them open
value.description: Charges for swimming clubs are set to increase after councillors agreed plans to make more use of high school swimming pools in Falkirk and help them break even.

value.description: Speaking ahead of a summit of Scottish party leaders called to address climate action, Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Alex Cole-Hamilton has outlined a package of immediate measures that his party wants to see implemented to bring down emissions,

value.name: Scottish government not committed to football regulator - but door remains open
value.description: Scottish sport minister Maree Todd will not commit to introducing an independent football regulator but stresses that the door remains open.

value.name: UK Government urged to stop arms sales to Israel by SNP MP petition
value.description: THE UK Government has been urged to stop selling weapons to Israel by a petition launched by an SNP MP and backed by his constituents.

value.name: Inverclyde MSP welcomes surge in new green energy
value.description: MSP Stuart McMillan says Inverclyde can play a key role in making Scotland a leader in renewable energy. The SNP man has welcomed the news that Scotland’s green energy sector has for the first time delivered more electricity than the country used.

value.description: The Scottish Tory leader pointed to an email which he said showed the Scottish Government was 'thinking about independence instead of focusing purely on public health'.

value.name: Second home owners in West Lothian could see council tax double
value.description: Second home owners in West Lothian could face paying double their current Council Tax on the properties in the new financial year. The increase - which could affect more than 80 homes - is planned as part of the measures to balance the council’s books in the 2024 budget.

value.name: Penny Mordaunt urged to reveal if she is a traitor or faithful amid Tory plots
value.description: Labour shadow Commons leader Lucy Powell raised questions about Ms Mordaunt’s ‘bizarre’ defence of the Prime Minister.

value.name: Sturgeon could ‘cry from one eye if she wanted to’, claims Scottish Secretary
value.description: Alister Jack tells Covid Inquiry he ‘didn’t believe for a minute’ that former first minister set aside independence aims during pandemic

value.name: 'Didn't believe her for a minute!' Top Tory savages Nicola Sturgeon over Covid tears
value.description: The former Scottish first minister choked back tears during an appearance before the Covid inquiry yesterday as she denied suggestions the Scottish Government looked to weaponise the crisis for her independence cause. But giving evidence today, Mr Jack claimed Ms Sturgeon "could cry from one eye if she wanted to".

value.name: ‘They were dying, and they’d not had their money’: Britain’s multibillion-pound equal pay scandal
value.description: In 2005, Glasgow council offered to compensate women for historic pay inequality. But it sold them short again – and soon workers all over the UK started fighting for what they were owed

value.name: Bid to raise Scotland's school start age gains cross-party support
value.description: All but one of Scotland's main political parties have backed the motion to raise the school starting age and create a national kindergarten system.

value.name: Jack: I didn’t delete some of my pandemic WhatsApps – I deleted them all
value.description: The Scottish Secretary told the Covid inquiry he ‘regrets’ the move, but he insisted he did not take Government decisions on messages.

value.name: Councils facing 'impossible' task of finding accommodation for homeless refugees
value.description: Council officials have told MSPs it is 'almost impossible' to find accommodation for homeless refugees. Hundreds of asylum seekers are facing homelessness due to a lack of suitable accommodation. Council officials have told MSPs it is “almost impossible” to find accommodation for homeless refugees following positive asylum decisions.

value.name: Glasgow taxi boss says only 12 vehicles LEZ ready as trade struggles
value.description: A Glasgow taxi boss has admitted tough market conditions and new low emission zone (LEZ) rules are making it a fight to keep his business going. Brian O'Hara said his firm once had 100 taxis but that number is now down to 30. So far he has managed to get only 12 vehicles to comply with LEZ rules.
